text: Encourages Governments, local authorities, the United Nations system and regional organizations, and invites donors and other assisting countries, to address the vulnerabilities and capacities of women and girls through gender-responsive programming, including with regard to sexual and reproductive health needs and means to address sexual and gender-based violence and various forms of exploitation during emergencies and in post-disaster environments, and the allocation of resources in their disaster risk reduction, response and recovery efforts in coordination with the Governments of affected countries;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<Governments>>, <<local authorities>>, the <<United Nations system>> and <<regional organizations>>, and *invites* <<donors>> and <<other assisting countries>>, to address the vulnerabilities and capacities of women and girls through [[gender-responsive programming]], including with regard to sexual and reproductive health needs and means to address sexual and gender-based violence and various forms of exploitation during emergencies and in post-disaster environments, and the [[allocation of resources]] in their disaster risk reduction, response and recovery efforts in coordination with the {{Governments of affected countries}};
uncertainties: Mapped 'donors' to 'ODA providers'; 'other assisting countries' normalized as 'assisting countries'. Classified 'gender-responsive programming' under 'policy' though it could be interpreted as programmes.

text: Encourages Member States, the United Nations and humanitarian organizations to strengthen efforts to prevent, mitigate and respond to the protection risks and needs of persons affected by disasters, including by increasing funding and support for such efforts, ensuring protection capacities in surge mechanisms and enhancing the provision of basic services, especially for the most vulnerable, from the very onset of disaster;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<Member States>>, the <<United Nations>> and <<humanitarian organizations>> to strengthen efforts to prevent, mitigate and respond to the protection risks and needs of persons affected by disasters, including by increasing [[funding]] and support for such efforts, ensuring [[protection capacities]] in surge mechanisms and enhancing the [[provision of basic services]], especially for the most vulnerable, from the very onset of disaster;
uncertainties: Classified “the United Nations” as UN (Secretariat) rather than UN System. Treated “protection capacities in surge mechanisms” as capacity building. Focused deliverable on “funding” (not “support,” which is vague).

text: Encourages Member States, humanitarian organizations and other relevant stakeholders, in the context of natural disasters, to ensure access to safe drinking water and adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all, including women and girls;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene
deliverables.deliverable: adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<Member States>>, <<humanitarian organizations>> and other relevant stakeholders, in the context of natural disasters, to ensure [[access to safe drinking water]] and [[adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene]] for all, including women and girls;
uncertainties: "humanitarian organizations" is broad and may include UN entities and NGOs; deliverable type could alternatively be categorized as infrastructure, but humanitarian_assistance seems most fitting in disaster context.

text: Emphasizes the importance of mainstreaming the perspective of persons with disabilities in disaster risk reduction, and recognizes the importance of non‑discrimination and their inclusive and active participation in and contribution to disaster risk reduction, preparedness, emergency response, recovery and transition from relief to development, as well as the implementation of systematic approaches, policies and programmes that are inclusive of and accessible to persons with disabilities, recognizing that persons with disabilities are disproportionately affected in humanitarian emergencies and face multiple obstacles in accessing humanitarian assistance, and recalls the Charter on Inclusion of Persons with Disabilities in Humanitarian Action;
textWithHighlights: *Emphasizes* the importance of mainstreaming the perspective of persons with disabilities in disaster risk reduction, and *recognizes* the importance of non‑discrimination and their inclusive and active participation in and contribution to disaster risk reduction, preparedness, emergency response, recovery and transition from relief to development, as well as the implementation of systematic approaches, policies and programmes that are inclusive of and accessible to persons with disabilities, recognizing that persons with disabilities are disproportionately affected in humanitarian emergencies and face multiple obstacles in accessing humanitarian assistance, and *recalls* the Charter on Inclusion of Persons with Disabilities in Humanitarian Action;

text: Encourages efforts to provide safe and enabling learning environments and access to quality education for all, especially for girls and boys, in humanitarian emergencies caused by natural disasters, including in order to contribute to a smooth transition from relief to development;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* efforts to provide [[safe and enabling learning environments]] and [[access to quality education]] for all, especially for girls and boys, in humanitarian emergencies caused by natural disasters, including in order to contribute to a smooth transition from relief to development;

text: Also encourages efforts to strengthen the disaster resilience and safety of schools, reduce interruptions to education during natural disasters, including interruptions to school meals, and in this regard encourages international support to countries that are vulnerable to natural hazards, as appropriate;

deliverables.deliverable: disaster resilience and safety of schools

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Reduced interruptions to education during disasters

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: countries that are vulnerable to natural hazards

textWithHighlights: Also *encourages* efforts to strengthen the [[disaster resilience and safety of schools]], [[reduce interruptions to education]] during natural disasters, including interruptions to school meals, and in this regard *encourages* [[international support]] to {{countries that are vulnerable to natural hazards}}, as appropriate;
uncertainties: No explicit assignee is named; the encouragement appears general. Deliverable type mapping is somewhat interpretive: strengthening school safety could also involve policy/standards, and reducing interruptions to education could be strategy/operations rather than policy. “International support” may include technical or humanitarian assistance in addition to financing.

text: Encourages Member States, the United Nations and humanitarian organizations to incorporate mental health and psychosocial support services into disaster preparedness, response and recovery;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Integrate mental health and psychosocial support services into disaster preparedness, response and recovery
deliverables.deliverable: mental health and psychosocial support services

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<Member States>>, the <<United Nations>> and <<humanitarian organizations>> to incorporate [[mental health and psychosocial support services]] into disaster preparedness, response and recovery;
uncertainties: "the United Nations" could refer to the UN Secretariat or the broader UN System; interpreted here as UN Secretariat (UN).

text: Encourages Member States and relevant regional and international organizations to identify and improve the dissemination of best practices, including in the context of COVID‑19, for improving disaster preparedness, response and early recovery and to scale up successful local initiatives, as appropriate;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<Member States>> and relevant <<regional>> and <<international organizations>> to identify and improve the [[dissemination of best practices]], including in the context of COVID‑19, for improving disaster preparedness, response and early recovery and to [[scale up successful local initiatives]], as appropriate;
uncertainties: Classified “scale up successful local initiatives” as capacity_building; it could also relate to strategy or resources depending on context.

text: Requests the United Nations humanitarian and development organizations to improve their coordination of disaster recovery efforts, from relief to development, inter alia, by strengthening institutional, coordination and strategic planning efforts in disaster preparedness, resilience-building and recovery, in support of national authorities, and by ensuring that development actors participate in strategic planning at an early stage;

assignees.assignee: United Nations humanitarian and development organizations

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Improved coordination of disaster recovery efforts
Strengthened institutional and strategic planning efforts for disaster preparedness, resilience-building and recovery
deliverables.deliverable: strengthening institutional, coordination and strategic planning efforts

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Participation of development actors in strategic planning at an early stage

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<United Nations humanitarian and development organizations>> to [[improve their coordination]] of disaster recovery efforts, from relief to development, inter alia, by [[strengthening institutional, coordination and strategic planning efforts]] in disaster preparedness, resilience-building and recovery, in support of {{national authorities}}, and by ensuring that {{development actors}} [[participate in strategic planning]] at an early stage;
uncertainties: Assignee normalization: "United Nations humanitarian and development organizations" could map to either the UN System broadly or the UN Development System; chosen "UN System" to include humanitarian entities. Deliverable typing is somewhat interpretive: "improve coordination" and "participate in strategic planning" classified under "strategy", while "strengthening institutional... efforts" under "capacity_building"; alternative classifications (policy/strategy) could also fit.

text: Encourages the United Nations and humanitarian and development organizations to support national, subnational and local governments and communities in their responsibility to develop long-term strategies, forecast-based financing and preparedness systems and multi-year operational plans for preparedness that are embedded within disaster risk reduction and resilience strategies in line with the Sendai Framework;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* the <<United Nations>> and <<humanitarian and development organizations>> to support national, subnational and local governments and communities in their responsibility to develop [[long-term strategies]], [[forecast-based financing]] and [[preparedness systems]] and [[multi-year operational plans for preparedness]] that are embedded within disaster risk reduction and resilience strategies in line with the Sendai Framework;
uncertainties: The clause 'that are embedded within disaster risk reduction and resilience strategies' may modify all listed items or only the operational plans. Classification of 'preparedness systems' as infrastructure could alternatively be seen as policy.

text: Calls upon the United Nations system and other humanitarian actors to improve the dissemination of tools and services to support enhanced disaster risk reduction, in particular preparedness, early action, rapid response and early recovery;
textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* the <<United Nations system>> and other humanitarian actors to improve the [[dissemination of tools and services]] to support enhanced disaster risk reduction, in particular preparedness, early action, rapid response and early recovery;
uncertainties: "other humanitarian actors" is broad and not mapped as a specific assignee.

text: Calls upon relevant United Nations humanitarian and development organizations, in consultation with Member States, to strengthen tools and mechanisms to ensure that early recovery needs and support are integrated into the planning and implementation of disaster preparedness, humanitarian response and development cooperation activities, as appropriate;

assignees.assignee: relevant United Nations humanitarian and development organizations

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Strengthened tools and mechanisms for integrating early recovery
Integration of early recovery into planning and implementation
deliverables.deliverable: integrated into the planning and implementation

textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* <<relevant United Nations humanitarian and development organizations>>, in consultation with {{Member States}}, to [[strengthen tools and mechanisms]] to ensure that early recovery needs and support are [[integrated into the planning and implementation]] of disaster preparedness, humanitarian response and development cooperation activities, as appropriate;
uncertainties: Assignee normalized to UN System; could also be interpreted as UN Development System and relevant Secretariat entities (e.g., OCHA).

text: Encourages the United Nations system and humanitarian organizations to continue their efforts to mainstream early recovery into humanitarian programming, acknowledges that early recovery is an important step towards resilience-building and should receive further funding, and encourages the provision of timely, flexible and predictable funding for early recovery, including through established and complementary humanitarian and development instruments;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Mainstream early recovery in humanitarian programming
Timely, flexible and predictable funding for early recovery

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* the <<United Nations system>> and <<humanitarian organizations>> to continue their efforts to [[mainstream early recovery]] into humanitarian programming, *acknowledges* that early recovery is an important step towards resilience-building and should receive further funding, and *encourages* the provision of timely, flexible and predictable [[funding for early recovery]], including through established and complementary humanitarian and development instruments;
uncertainties: Classifying “humanitarian organizations” as an assignee (type: other) may be broad. The deliverable type for “mainstream early recovery” is set to policy; it could arguably fit strategy as well.

text: Urges Member States, the United Nations and humanitarian and development organizations to prioritize risk management and shift towards an anticipatory approach to humanitarian crises in order to prevent and reduce human suffering and economic losses; and encourages scaling up of early warning and early action systems, forecasting, prevention-oriented responses and emergency preparedness, strengthening of their coordination, coherence, complementarity and impact, and an increase in the use of disaster risk analysis, climate science, predictive analytics, reinforcing systematic risk monitoring and the sharing of data and analysis across sectors and at all levels to better prevent and address disaster and climate risks and impacts;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Early warning and early action systems scaled up
deliverables.deliverable: early warning and early action systems

textWithHighlights: *Urges* <<Member States>>, the <<United Nations>> and <<humanitarian and development organizations>> to prioritize [[risk management]] and shift towards an [[anticipatory approach]] to humanitarian crises in order to prevent and reduce human suffering and economic losses; and *encourages* scaling up of [[early warning and early action systems]], [[forecasting]], [[prevention-oriented responses]] and [[emergency preparedness]], strengthening of their [[coordination]], coherence, complementarity and impact, and an increase in the use of [[disaster risk analysis]], climate science, [[predictive analytics]], reinforcing [[systematic risk monitoring]] and the [[sharing of data and analysis]] across sectors and at all levels to better prevent and address disaster and climate risks and impacts;
uncertainties: The second clause with 'encourages' has no explicit assignee; it likely refers to the same actors listed after 'Urges', but this is not stated, so assignees are left empty. Categorization of some deliverables (e.g., prevention-oriented responses, coordination, emergency preparedness) could arguably fit other categories such as strategy or capacity building.

text: Also urges Member States, as well as the United Nations, and humanitarian organizations, in accordance with their respective mandates and in line with humanitarian principles, to continue to scale up anticipatory approaches, early warning early action systems, forecasting, prevention-oriented responses and emergency preparedness, and improve predictive and risk data analytics across sectors, reinforce systematic risk monitoring, early warning and preparedness capacities at the local, national, regional and global levels, including, inter alia, the use of anticipatory financing approaches for humanitarian emergencies, and to consider further efforts by the United Nations humanitarian system and other relevant stakeholders in this regard;
textWithHighlights: Also *urges* <<Member States>>, as well as the <<United Nations>>, and <<humanitarian organizations>>, in accordance with their respective mandates and in line with humanitarian principles, to continue to scale up anticipatory approaches, [[early warning early action systems]], [[forecasting]], prevention-oriented responses and [[emergency preparedness]], and improve [[predictive and risk data analytics]] across sectors, reinforce [[systematic risk monitoring]], early warning and [[preparedness capacities]] at the local, national, regional and global levels, including, inter alia, the use of [[anticipatory financing approaches]] for humanitarian emergencies, and to consider further efforts by the {{United Nations humanitarian system}} and other relevant stakeholders in this regard;
uncertainties: "United Nations" as an assignee could refer to the UN Secretariat versus the broader UN system; mapped here to UN (Secretariat). Deliverable categorizations (e.g., classifying early warning systems as infrastructure and preparedness/emergency preparedness as capacity building) involve some judgment.

text: Recalls its decision to hold a midterm review of the implementation of the Sendai Framework in 2023, and in this regard welcomes the convening of the high-level meeting on the midterm review of the Sendai Framework on 18 and 19 May 2023, at which the General Assembly adopted the political declaration on the midterm review of the Sendai Framework;
textWithHighlights: *Recalls* its decision to hold a midterm review of the implementation of the Sendai Framework in 2023, and in this regard *welcomes* the convening of the high-level meeting on the midterm review of the Sendai Framework on 18 and 19 May 2023, at which the {{General Assembly}} adopted the political declaration on the midterm review of the Sendai Framework;

text: Encourages international financial institutions to accelerate anticipatory financing at scale for preparedness and response as well as for risk-informed resilient recovery, including pre‑agreed contingency financing, in ways that complement and reinforce humanitarian pooled funds;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<international financial institutions>> to accelerate [[anticipatory financing]] at scale for preparedness and response as well as for risk-informed resilient recovery, including [[pre‑agreed contingency financing]], in ways that complement and reinforce humanitarian pooled funds;

text: Urges Member States, humanitarian and development organizations and other stakeholders to ensure a comprehensive and coherent approach at the global, regional, national and local levels to El Niño and La Niña phenomena and similar or related events, including by strengthening forecasting, early warning and early action, prevention, preparedness, resilience-building and timely response, supported by effective leadership and predictable, adequate and early funding, when feasible, in regions, countries and communities likely to be affected, and notes the work of the Special Envoys of the Secretary-General on El Niño and Climate and the blueprint for action prepared by them, and the standard operating procedures for El Niño/ Southern Oscillation events of the Inter-Agency Standing Committee;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Special Envoys of the Secretary-General on El Niño and Climate
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Special Envoys of the Secretary-General on El Niño and Climate

textWithHighlights: *Urges* <<Member States>>, <<humanitarian and development organizations>> and other stakeholders to ensure a comprehensive and coherent approach at the global, regional, national and local levels to El Niño and La Niña phenomena and similar or related events, including by strengthening [[forecasting]], [[early warning]] and early action, prevention, preparedness, resilience-building and timely response, supported by effective leadership and predictable, adequate and early [[funding]], when feasible, in regions, countries and communities likely to be affected, and *notes* the work of the {{Special Envoys of the Secretary-General on El Niño and Climate}} and the blueprint for action prepared by them, and the standard operating procedures for El Niño/ Southern Oscillation events of the {{Inter-Agency Standing Committee}};
uncertainties: The tasks to strengthen forecasting, early warning, and related capacities are broad; classified 'early warning' as capacity_building though it could also imply systems/infrastructure. 'Humanitarian and development organizations' is treated as a single assignee (not split) to match the contiguous text. The 'Special Envoys of the Secretary-General on El Niño and Climate' and the Inter-Agency Standing Committee are not in the provided entity list and are added as 'other' mentioned entities.

text: Notes that the El Niño/La Niña phenomenon has a recurring character and can lead to extensive natural hazards with the potential to seriously affect populations, encourages Member States, humanitarian and development organizations and other stakeholders, in accordance with their respective mandates, to increase support, including financial, technical and capacity-building, as appropriate, for people and communities affected by and most vulnerable to these phenomena, including to meet and reduce humanitarian needs, and to prevent and address loss of livelihoods, increased food insecurity, and impacts on health, water and sanitation, education, agriculture and other sectors, and encourages increased cooperation with regional and subregional organizations and international financial institutions, and further encourages increased investment in national and local response mechanisms, climate adaptation and community resilience;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: increased investment in response mechanisms, climate adaptation and community resilience

textWithHighlights: *Notes* that the El Niño/La Niña phenomenon has a recurring character and can lead to extensive natural hazards with the potential to seriously affect populations, *encourages* <<Member States>>, <<humanitarian and development organizations>> and other stakeholders, in accordance with their respective mandates, to increase support, including [[financial]], [[technical]] and [[capacity-building]], as appropriate, for people and communities affected by and most vulnerable to these phenomena, including to meet and reduce humanitarian needs, and to prevent and address loss of livelihoods, increased food insecurity, and impacts on health, water and sanitation, education, agriculture and other sectors, and *encourages* increased cooperation with {{regional and subregional organizations}} and {{international financial institutions}}, and *further encourages* [[increased investment]] in national and local response mechanisms, climate adaptation and community resilience;
uncertainties: Assignee classification for “humanitarian and development organizations” is broad; kept as a single 'other' assignee. Did not mark “increased cooperation” as a deliverable due to vagueness. Normalized “regional and subregional organizations” to 'regional organizations' for mentioned entity type coverage.

text: Encourages Member States and the United Nations to enhance the use of common risk analysis, including the use of the Index for Risk Management, to establish the evidence base for short-, medium- and long-term planning and joint strategies for disaster and climate risk management, capacity development and resilience-building, allowing for greater prioritization of resources where the risk is greatest;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<Member States>> and the <<United Nations>> to enhance the use of [[common risk analysis]], including the use of the Index for Risk Management, to establish the [[evidence base]] for short-, medium- and long-term planning and joint strategies for disaster and climate risk management, capacity development and resilience-building, allowing for greater prioritization of resources where the risk is greatest;

text: Encourages the United Nations and humanitarian and development organizations to work towards a common understanding of underlying risks, clarify roles and responsibilities according to their respective mandates and establish joint objectives and programmes informed by affected people, data and analysis to strengthen coordination, collaboration and coherence among short-, medium- and long-term activities to progressively reduce needs and vulnerability, build resilience and manage the risk related to climate change and of disasters and development setbacks over multi-year planning cycles, including through integrating risk management into national sustainable development plans and ensuring the connectivity of humanitarian plans with the longer-term sustainable development priorities of Member States, with a view to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Integration of risk management into national sustainable development plans
deliverables.deliverable: integrating risk management into national sustainable development plans

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Connectivity of humanitarian plans with long-term sustainable development priorities

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* the <<United Nations>> and <<humanitarian and development organizations>> to work towards a [[common understanding of underlying risks]], clarify [[roles and responsibilities]] according to their respective mandates and establish [[joint objectives and programmes]] informed by affected people, data and analysis to strengthen coordination, collaboration and coherence among short-, medium- and long-term activities to progressively reduce needs and vulnerability, build resilience and manage the risk related to climate change and of disasters and development setbacks over multi-year planning cycles, including through [[integrating risk management into national sustainable development plans]] and ensuring the [[connectivity of humanitarian plans]] with the longer-term sustainable development priorities of {{Member States}}, with a view to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals;
uncertainties: “United Nations” could be interpreted as the UN system rather than specifically the UN Secretariat; deliverable categorization between policy vs. strategy vs. analysis could be interpreted differently. The integration into national plans may imply Member State action, but the encouragement is addressed to the UN and organizations to support/ensure this.

text: Stresses the need to strengthen resilience at all levels, and in this regard encourages Member States, the United Nations system and other relevant actors to support efforts, as appropriate, to integrate resilience into humanitarian and development programming, and encourages humanitarian and development actors to pursue, where appropriate, common resilience and risk management objectives, achievable through joint analysis, planning, programming and funding;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Integration of resilience into humanitarian and development programming
deliverables.deliverable: integrate resilience into humanitarian and development programming

textWithHighlights: *Stresses* the need to strengthen resilience at all levels, and in this regard *encourages* <<Member States>>, the <<United Nations system>> and other relevant actors to support efforts, as appropriate, to [[integrate resilience into humanitarian and development programming]], and *encourages* <<humanitarian and development actors>> to pursue, where appropriate, common resilience and risk management objectives, achievable through joint analysis, planning, programming and funding;
uncertainties: Whether to treat “humanitarian and development actors” as concrete assignees (classified as other) and whether the means listed (joint analysis, planning, programming and funding) should be extracted as deliverables; opted to be conservative and not extract them as deliverables.

text: Encourages Member States, international financial institutions and the private sector to support further development and, where appropriate, the strengthening of anticipatory financing approaches, to mobilize predictable and multi-year support and to work collectively towards common results in order to reduce need, risk and vulnerability, making use of a wide range of financing flows and instruments and partnerships to mobilize additional resources in the field of natural disasters;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Development and strengthening of anticipatory financing approaches
Mobilization of predictable and multi-year support
Mobilization of additional resources for natural disasters

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<Member States>>, <<international financial institutions>> and the <<private sector>> to support further development and, where appropriate, the strengthening of [[anticipatory financing approaches]], to mobilize [[predictable and multi-year support]] and to work collectively towards common results in order to reduce need, risk and vulnerability, making use of a wide range of financing flows and instruments and partnerships to mobilize [[additional resources]] in the field of natural disasters;
uncertainties: Classifying the development/strengthening of anticipatory financing approaches as a 'policy' deliverable could alternatively be seen as 'strategy'.

text: Calls upon Member States, the United Nations and humanitarian organizations to provide emergency assistance in ways that are supportive of recovery and long-term development, in collaboration with development organizations, as appropriate, in accordance with their respective mandates, including by prioritizing humanitarian tools and approaches that strengthen resilience, including preparedness, and support livelihoods, and to support further development and, where appropriate, the strengthening of anticipatory financing approaches, such as, but not limited to, cash transfers, vouchers, local procurement of food and services and social safety nets;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: local procurement of food and services
deliverables.deliverable: local procurement of food and services

textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* <<Member States>>, the <<United Nations>> and <<humanitarian organizations>> to provide [[emergency assistance]] in ways that are supportive of recovery and long-term development, in collaboration with {{development organizations}}, as appropriate, in accordance with their respective mandates, including by prioritizing humanitarian tools and approaches that strengthen resilience, including preparedness, and support livelihoods, and to support further development and, where appropriate, the strengthening of [[anticipatory financing approaches]], such as, but not limited to, [[cash transfers]], [[vouchers]], [[local procurement of food and services]] and [[social safety nets]];
uncertainties: "United Nations" could refer to the UN Secretariat or the broader UN system; mapped to UN Secretariat (UN). The categorization of "local procurement of food and services" and "social safety nets" as financial_resources is somewhat interpretive; they are examples of anticipatory financing approaches but could also be seen as policy/instrument or humanitarian modalities.

text: Encourages the United Nations system and other relevant humanitarian and development actors to support humanitarian coordinators and resident coordinators in order to strengthen their capacity, inter alia, to support the host Government in implementing preparedness measures and to coordinate preparedness activities of country teams in support of national efforts, and encourages the United Nations system and other relevant humanitarian actors to further strengthen the ability to quickly and flexibly deploy humanitarian professionals to support Governments and country teams in the immediate aftermath of a disaster;

deliverables.deliverable: support humanitarian coordinators and resident coordinators

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Strengthen capacity of humanitarian and resident coordinators
Strengthen ability to deploy humanitarian professionals
deliverables.deliverable: ability to quickly and flexibly deploy humanitarian professionals

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* the <<United Nations system>> and other relevant humanitarian and development actors to [[support humanitarian coordinators and resident coordinators]] in order to [[strengthen their capacity]], inter alia, to support the {{host Government}} in implementing preparedness measures and to coordinate preparedness activities of {{country teams}} in support of national efforts, and *encourages* the <<United Nations system>> and other relevant humanitarian actors to further strengthen the [[ability to quickly and flexibly deploy humanitarian professionals]] to support {{Governments}} and {{country teams}} in the immediate aftermath of a disaster;

text: Encourages Member States, the United Nations and humanitarian and development organizations to identify ways to improve the current financing architecture in order to better provide coherent, predictable and flexible longer-term funding for risk management in multi-year strategies and forecasting, in particular preparedness, on the basis of a global assessment of risk, allowing for better prioritization of resources where the risk is greatest;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<Member States>>, the <<United Nations>> and <<humanitarian and development organizations>> to identify ways to improve the current financing architecture in order to better provide coherent, predictable and flexible longer-term funding for risk management in multi-year strategies and forecasting, in particular preparedness, on the basis of a global assessment of risk, allowing for better prioritization of resources where the risk is greatest;
uncertainties: "United Nations" could mean the UN Secretariat or the broader UN System; classified here as UN Secretariat. The tasks (identify ways to improve financing architecture, provide longer-term funding) are broad and not captured as concrete deliverables.

text: Recognizes that enhanced access to international climate finance is important to support mitigation and adaptation efforts in developing countries, especially those that are particularly vulnerable to the adverse effects of climate change, and also recognizes the ongoing efforts in this regard;
textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* that enhanced access to international climate finance is important to support mitigation and adaptation efforts in {{developing countries}}, especially those that are particularly vulnerable to the adverse effects of climate change, and also *recognizes* the ongoing efforts in this regard;

text: Urges Member States, international financial institutions and other relevant stakeholders to scale up finance for adaptation and disaster risk reduction to countries and local communities that are affected by compound risks caused by humanitarian emergencies and vulnerability to natural hazards and the adverse effects of climate change to prevent, mitigate, adapt and respond to disaster impacts, to reduce humanitarian needs, risks and vulnerabilities related to disasters and to build resilience to shocks;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Increased financing for adaptation and disaster risk reduction

textWithHighlights: *Urges* <<Member States>>, <<international financial institutions>> and other relevant stakeholders to [[scale up finance]] for adaptation and disaster risk reduction to countries and local communities that are affected by compound risks caused by humanitarian emergencies and vulnerability to natural hazards and the adverse effects of climate change to prevent, mitigate, adapt and respond to disaster impacts, to reduce humanitarian needs, risks and vulnerabilities related to disasters and to build resilience to shocks;
uncertainties: "other relevant stakeholders" is broad and not treated as a specific assignee.

text: Emphasizes the need to mobilize adequate, flexible and sustainable resources for preparedness and disaster risk reduction, early action, rapid response and early recovery activities in order to ensure predictable and timely access to resources for humanitarian assistance in emergencies resulting from disasters associated with natural hazards;
textWithHighlights: *Emphasizes* the need to mobilize adequate, flexible and sustainable resources for preparedness and disaster risk reduction, early action, rapid response and early recovery activities in order to ensure predictable and timely access to resources for humanitarian assistance in emergencies resulting from disasters associated with natural hazards;

text: Calls upon donors to fund humanitarian response plans and flash appeals for disaster responses in order to further reinforce the effectiveness, sustainability, predictability and timely delivery of humanitarian assistance to people affected by disasters, including those in hard-to-reach areas, and to scale up timely and predictable funding and innovative and anticipatory financing mechanisms, as well as by strengthening partnerships with international financial institutions in order to prevent, reduce and respond to humanitarian suffering and assist those in need;

deliverables.deliverable: fund humanitarian response plans and flash appeals

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Scale up timely and predictable funding
deliverables.deliverable: scale up timely and predictable funding

textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* <<donors>> to [[fund humanitarian response plans and flash appeals]] for disaster responses in order to further reinforce the effectiveness, sustainability, predictability and timely delivery of humanitarian assistance to people affected by disasters, including those in hard-to-reach areas, and to [[scale up timely and predictable funding]] and [[innovative and anticipatory financing mechanisms]], as well as by [[strengthening partnerships]] with {{international financial institutions}} in order to prevent, reduce and respond to humanitarian suffering and assist those in need;
uncertainties: "Donors" is broad; mapped as other rather than specifically to Member States/ODA providers. "Strengthening partnerships" is treated as a deliverable of type strategy; some frameworks might not count it as a concrete deliverable.

text: Welcomes the important achievements of the Central Emergency Response Fund in ensuring a more timely and predictable response to humanitarian emergencies, stresses the importance of continuing to improve the functioning of the Fund, and in this regard encourages the United Nations funds and programmes and the specialized agencies to review and evaluate, where necessary, their partnership policies and practices in order to ensure the timely disbursement of funds from the Fund to implementing partners in order to ensure that resources are used in the most efficient, effective, accountable and transparent manner possible;

Evaluation of partnership policies and practices

textWithHighlights: *Welcomes* the important achievements of the {{Central Emergency Response Fund}} in ensuring a more timely and predictable response to humanitarian emergencies, *stresses* the importance of continuing to improve the functioning of the Fund, and in this regard *encourages* the <<United Nations funds and programmes>> and the <<specialized agencies>> to [[review]] and [[evaluate]], where necessary, their partnership policies and practices in order to ensure the timely disbursement of funds from the Fund to implementing partners in order to ensure that resources are used in the most efficient, effective, accountable and transparent manner possible;

text: Calls upon all Member States, and invites the private sector and all concerned individuals and institutions, to consider increasing their voluntary contributions to the Central Emergency Response Fund in order to achieve an annual funding level of 1 billion United States dollars, and to continue to reinforce and strengthen the Fund as the global emergency response fund, and emphasizes that contributions should be additional to current commitments to humanitarian programming and should not be to the detriment of resources made available for international cooperation for development;

text: Also calls upon Member States to continue to increase support to the Central Emergency Response Fund and humanitarian country-based and regional pooled funds for strengthening early and rapid response to mitigate the impact of disasters, including in underfunded contexts and increasingly through local and national responders and implementing partners;

textWithHighlights: Also *calls upon* <<Member States>> to continue to [[increase support]] to the Central Emergency Response Fund and humanitarian country-based and regional pooled funds for strengthening early and rapid response to mitigate the impact of disasters, including in underfunded contexts and increasingly through local and national responders and implementing partners;
uncertainties: Did not mark the Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) or country-based/regional pooled funds as mentioned entities since they are not in the provided entity list; treated them as part of the deliverable context.

text: Invites Member States, the private sector and all other relevant stakeholders to harness their differentiated skills, capacities and resources, and also to consider voluntary contributions to humanitarian funding mechanisms;
textWithHighlights: *Invites* <<Member States>>, the <<private sector>> and all other relevant stakeholders to harness their differentiated skills, capacities and resources, and also to consider [[voluntary contributions]] to humanitarian funding mechanisms;

text: Strongly encourages giving appropriate consideration to disaster risk reduction, including preparedness, and the building of resilience to disasters as integral elements of sustainable development and in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development and promoting a complementary and coherent approach between those Agendas and the Sendai Framework;
textWithHighlights: *Strongly encourages* giving appropriate consideration to disaster risk reduction, including preparedness, and the building of resilience to disasters as integral elements of sustainable development and in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development and promoting a complementary and coherent approach between those Agendas and the Sendai Framework;
uncertainties: No explicit assignee is stated; likely intended for Member States and stakeholders generally, but not specified.

text: Strongly encourages all relevant actors to work to ensure a comprehensive, coherent, systematic and people-centred approach to managing risks, including through, as appropriate, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the Sendai Framework, the Paris Agreement and the New Urban Agenda;

text: Takes note of the World Humanitarian Summit, held in Istanbul, Turkey, on 23 and 24 May 2016, and of the report of the Secretary-General on the outcome of the World Humanitarian Summit;
textWithHighlights: *Takes note* of the World Humanitarian Summit, held in Istanbul, Turkey, on 23 and 24 May 2016, and of the report of the {{Secretary-General}} on the outcome of the World Humanitarian Summit;

text: Requests the Secretary-General to continue to improve the international response to natural disasters and to report thereon to the General Assembly at its eightieth session and to include in his report recommendations on how to ensure that humanitarian assistance is provided in ways supportive of the transition from relief to development.
